content: # Flue System Diagnostics and Fault Finding Guide

This comprehensive guide covers diagnostic procedures for flue systems in both conventional and condensing boilers, addressing issues with flue gas recirculation, terminal positioning, condensate problems, and shared flue systems.
- **Room-Sealed Appliance Connection**: Direct connection to outdoors
- **Twin Flue Systems**: Separate air intake and exhaust
- **Cascade Systems**: Multiple boilers with common collector
- Diameter requirements based on appliance output
- Temperature rating appropriate for appliance type
- Intermittent lockouts on flue gas sensors
- Smell of combustion products near boiler/terminal
- Check terminal positioning relative to openings
- Check for obstructions that may redirect gases
- Verify terminal guard hasn't been modified
- Inspect for damage to flue components
- Monitor combustion readings at steady state
- Check readings with windows/doors open vs. closed
- Test operation in different wind conditions if possible
- Check readings at minimum and maximum firing rates
- Verify operation of any mechanical ventilation
- Use smoke pellets to visualize air flow patterns
- Test with boiler running and not running
- Observe for smoke drawn into air intakes
- Symptoms: Recirculation under certain wind conditions
- Cause: Terminal too close to openings or corners
* Relocate terminal to comply with regulations
* Consider wind deflectors if relocation impossible
- Cause: Inadequate separation of exhaust and intake
* Install condensate drain point if needed
- Visible plume is water vapor condensing in air
- Measure plume length in different conditions
- Verify appropriate terminal type for location
- Evaluate plume's impact on building materials
- Symptoms: Customer complaints, staining on buildings
- Cause: Normal operation but problematic location
- Symptoms: Unusually large or persistent plume
- Cause: Possibly low efficiency, poor combustion
* Verify boiler operating at condensing temperatures
- Identify if surrounding environment has changed
- Check if terminal has been moved
- Verify if original installation documentation exists
- Symptoms: Terminal too close to openings, boundaries
- Cause: Incorrect installation, subsequent building changes
* Consider alternative terminal types if relocation difficult
* Seek Building Control approval for exceptional circumstances
- Symptoms: Terminal too low to ground or roof
- Cause: Installation error, ground level changes
* Consider vertical termination if horizontal positioning problematic
* Address any access issues for future maintenance
- Check if cycling affects certain burner rates more
- Monitor temperature sensors during cycling events
- Check for pressure fluctuations at terminal
- Verify if external wind affects combustion air
- Symptoms: Cycling during specific wind conditions
- Cause: Terminal position relative to building features
* Relocate terminal away from negative pressure zones
- Symptoms: Cycling related to building pressure zones
- Cause: Terminal located in turbulent or negative pressure area
* Move terminal to neutral pressure zone
## PART 4: CONDENSATE BACKFLOW IN FLUE PIPES
- Gurgling or bubbling sounds in flue
- Check for water stains on ceiling/walls near flue
- Inspect flue joints for signs of leakage
- Look for corrosion on metal components
- Check integrity of seals and gaskets
- Check proper slope of horizontal sections (3° min)
- Verify presence and location of condensate collection points
- Check for low points where condensate might collect
- Run boiler through temperature range to generate condensate
- Check for condensate ejection at terminal
- Symptoms: Condensate pooling, gurgling, eventual leaks
- Cause: Horizontal sections with insufficient fall
* Reposition flue to ensure minimum 3° fall
* Add condensate drain points at low spots
* Ensure fall toward appliance or designated drain point
- Symptoms: Water backing up, leaking joints
- Cause: Debris, soot, or ice blocking condensate drains
* Ensure proper engagement of push-fit components
* Check that all joints are secured properly
- Cause: Improper terminal design for location
* Install rain cap or shield if appropriate
- Individual appliance flues connecting to common vertical flue
- Each appliance typically has independent air supply
- Often found in apartment buildings with conventional boilers
- Combined flue and air supply in concentric arrangement
- Shared air supply and flue gas paths
- Modern systems for multiple condensing boilers
- May include cascade controls and flue dampers
- Parts of system may be inaccessible
- Responsibility may be shared among multiple parties
- Building management involvement may be required
- Pressure fluctuations can cause multiple symptoms
- Simultaneous operation creates different conditions than individual testing
- Check that all connected appliances are compatible
- Test individual appliances in isolation if possible
- Progressively add additional appliances to operation
- Check flame stability across operational range
- Smoke testing to visualize flow patterns
- Symptoms: Operation of one appliance affects others
- Cause: Damaged flue lips, missing baffles, incorrect connections
* Inspect and repair connections to main flue
* Verify correct installation of each appliance connection
* Check for missing or damaged components
* Ensure proper sealing of unused connections
- Symptoms: Poor performance when multiple appliances operate
- Cause: Flue sizing inadequate for combined maximum output
* Verify that connected load hasn't increased
* Consider operational adjustments to limit simultaneous demand
* Assess need for system redesign if undersized
- Cause: Inadequate condensate drainage in shared system
* Verify function of all drain points
* Check for proper slope throughout system
* Consider additional drainage points if needed
* Check operation of any mechanical draft controls
* Verify proper terminal design and positioning
- Check pressure at different external wind conditions
- Test with doors/windows open and closed
- Document performance variations in different seasons
- Check impact of building heating system operation
- Modified control strategies based on external conditions
1. Initial external inspection of all accessible components
- CO and CO₂ levels at different firing rates
- Uses non-toxic smoke to visualize flow patterns
- Reveals hot spots and cold bridges
- Identifies problematic areas for terminal positioning
- Shows impact of wind on system
*Note: Always refer to current regulations and manufacturer specifications as these may vary*
| Parameter | Natural Draught | Fan Flued | Condensing | Potential Issue if Outside Range |
| CO₂ (%) | 7-10 | 7-10 | 8.5-10.5 | Combustion issue, air supply problem |
| Flue Temp (°C) | 150-250 | 130-200 | 30-80 | Heat exchanger fouling, improper condensing |
| Pressure (Pa) | -5 to +5 | +10 to +100 | +10 to +150 | Flue restriction, fan issues |
| Material | Temperature Rating | Condensate Resistance | Common Applications | Notes |
| PP (Polypropylene) | 120°C | Excellent | Most domestic condensing | Cannot be used for conventional |
| Stainless Steel (316) | 250°C+ | Good | Conventional and condensing | Higher cost, longer lifespan |
| Aluminum | 200°C+ | Poor-Fair | Some conventional | Requires condensate management |
| PVDF | 160°C | Excellent | Industrial, high-efficiency | Highest cost, highest resistance |
| Problem | Possible Causes | Diagnostic Checks | Solutions |
| Recirculation | Terminal position, wind conditions | Gas analyzer, smoke test | Relocate terminal, plume kit |
| Condensate leakage | Poor joints, inadequate slope | Visual inspection, pressure test | Reseal, adjust slope, add drains |
| Noise | Turbulence, condensate, restrictions | Sound analysis, flow testing | Add supports, resolve turbulence points |
| Terminal damage | Environmental exposure, impact | Visual inspection | Replace, relocate, add protection |
| Shared flue issues | Cross-contamination, sizing | Pressure testing, CCTV inspection | Repair connections, balance system |
